Sentencas: The viability of cooling a solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) during air exposure is investigated as a possible solution to the mechanical damage caused by inadvertent 'redox cycling' (cyclic exposure to air and then to H-2) of Ni-based anode-supported cells at high temperatures.
Titulo: A possible solution to the mechanical degradation of Ni-yttria stabilized zirconia anode-supported solid oxide fuel cells due to redox cycling

Sentencas: In order to prevent electrolyte (and cell) cracking, it is shown that cooling the anode-supported Ni-YSZ samples during air exposure from 800 degrees C to <600 degrees C at rates >3 degrees C min(-1) significantly slows down the oxidation of Ni.
Titulo: A possible solution to the mechanical degradation of Ni-yttria stabilized zirconia anode-supported solid oxide fuel cells due to redox cycling

Sentencas: This, in turn, minimizes the volume expansion due to NiO formation.
Titulo: A possible solution to the mechanical degradation of Ni-yttria stabilized zirconia anode-supported solid oxide fuel cells due to redox cycling

Sentencas: Cell cooling rates of <3 degrees C min(-1) result in the cracking of the thin electrolyte layer, as sufficient time is then available for substantial NiO formation.
Titulo: A possible solution to the mechanical degradation of Ni-yttria stabilized zirconia anode-supported solid oxide fuel cells due to redox cycling

Sentencas: It is also shown that partial oxidation during cool-down results in more extensive Ni oxidation in the outer regions of the anode layer compared to regions closer to the electrolyte.
Titulo: A possible solution to the mechanical degradation of Ni-yttria stabilized zirconia anode-supported solid oxide fuel cells due to redox cycling

Sentencas: For the anode-supported cells investigated here, the electrolyte resists cracking when the nearby Ni particles (within 10-20 mu m of the electrolyte) are prevented from oxidizing to an extent of more than 65%.
Titulo: A possible solution to the mechanical degradation of Ni-yttria stabilized zirconia anode-supported solid oxide fuel cells due to redox cycling
